summary: This document records the preparation of David Rodgers (a pilot for Jeffrey Epstein) by prosecutors for trial testimony. It details his review of a photobook where he identified Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, his recollections about Epstein's helicopter operations, Maxwell's role, and his practices regarding flight logs and NDAs.

events.title: Preparation of David Rodgers for Trial
events.description: Prosecutors prepare pilot David Rodgers for trial testimony, showing him a photobook and questioning him about his recollections.

events.title: Epstein Purchases First Helicopters
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein first purchased private helicopters around 2002 or 2003, eventually owning about four.

events.title: Rodgers Stops Logging Passenger Names
events.description: David Rodgers stopped recording passenger names in his flight logbook based on a conversation with one of Epstein's attorneys.

events.title: Rodgers Stops Keeping Logbook Entirely

events.title: Maxwell's Reduced Flight Presence
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell spent significantly less time on Epstein's private planes around 2005 or 2006, after being on about half of all flights from approximately 1991 to 2005.

keyFacts: Pilot David Rodgers identified Jeffrey Epstein (photo 7) and Ghislaine Maxwell (photo 16) in a photobook shown by prosecutors.
Rodgers described Ghislaine Maxwell as the 'number 2' in Epstein's employee hierarchy, directly below him, through whom other employees had to go.
Rodgers stopped recording passenger names in his flight logbook in 2007 after a conversation with one of Epstein's attorneys, and stopped keeping a logbook entirely in 2013.
Rodgers recalled signing an NDA early in his employment with Epstein and believed it may have originated from Leslie Wexner, for whom Epstein was working at the time.
Maxwell was on about half of Epstein's private flights from approximately 1991 to 2005, but her presence significantly decreased around 2005 or 2006.
